abstract.text: MiniBooNE anti-neutrino charged-current quasi-elastic (CCQE) data is compared to model predictions.
The main background of neutrino-induced events is examined first, where three independent techniques are employed.
Results indicate the neutrino flux is consistent with a uniform reduction of ∼ 20% relative to the largely uncertain prediction.

After background subtraction, the Q 2 shape ofν µ CCQE events is consistent with the model parameter M A = 1.35 GeV determined from MiniBooNE ν µ CCQE data, while the normalization is ∼ 20% high compared to the same prediction.

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION

The charged-current quasi-elastic interaction (CCQE, ν l + N → l + N ) has become a hot topic lately, as many recent measurements on nuclear targets are in tension with previous results mostly from light nuclear targets.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Even more recently, theoretical work looking to explain these data suggest the widely-used Fermi Gas model [1] is insufficient for scattering in a nuclear environment, where intra-nuclear correlations may play a larger role than previously expected [2,3,4].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Significant effects from multi-nucleon correlations in a nuclear environment are also seen in electron scattering data [5].
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Anti-neutrino CCQE provides a strong test of the underlying physics by probing a different mix of axial and vector terms compared to neutrino-induced CCQE.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: No antineutrino CCQE measurement has been made below 1 GeV, and few exist on nuclear targets.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The work presented here represents one of the final steps of MiniBooNE data analysis before producing absolute, differential and double-differential anti-neutrino CCQE cross sections on a nuclear target around 1 GeV.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The MiniBooNE detector is non-magnetized, so a dedicated study of the ν µ background is necessary before a meaningful appraisal of the anti-neutrino CCQE rate and shape can be made.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Three independent techniques to measure the neutrino component of the anti-neutrino mode data are presented, followed by comparisons between antineutrino CCQE data and model predictions.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING
The MiniBooNE flux prediction uses dedicated π ± double-differential cross section measurements from the HARP experiment [6].
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: As Figure 1 shows, most of the production phase space of so-called "right-sign" particles (i.e., neutrinos in the neutrino-mode beam and anti-neutrinos in the anti-neutrino mode beam) are covered by the HARP data.
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: However, "wrong-sign" particles mostly arise from very forward-going pions that escape deflection by the magnetic horn, and this region is not covered by the HARP data.
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: Most of the wrong-sign MiniBooNE flux prediction is therefore extrapolated from the existing HARP data and is largely uncertain.
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: Clearly, a dedicated study of the neutrino content of the primarily anti-neutrino beam must be made before precise anti-neutrino CCQE cross sections can be made.
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: Three independent and complementary measurements of this crucial background are presented in this section: we evaluate charged-curent single π + (CC1π + , ν l + N → l + N + π) event rates, exploit µ − capture in the detector medium, and finally the muon angular distribution of the CCQE sample is fit to a sum of the simulated ν µ andν µ distributions to measure the neutrino component of the anti-neutrino beam.
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: In all three measurements, the relevant ν µ channels in simulation have been corrected to reflect the observed cross sections from neutrino-mode data, and therefore the measurements are interpreted as a flux calibration.
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: The CC1π + and CCQE angular fit methods and results are presented in more detail in Ref.
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING
MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: This work represents the first measurement of the neutrino component of an anti-neutrino beam using a non-magnetized detector.
body_text.section: MEASUREMENTS OF THE NEUTRINO FLUX IN ANTI-NEUTRINO RUNNING

body_text.text: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement
By simple charge and lepton number conservation, the CC1π interaction yields π + (π − ) for an incident ν (ν).
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: In a carbon nuclear environment, stopped π − experience capture at a rate of ∼100% [8].
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: In this analysis, pions are identified only by the decay chain leading to the production of electrons from decay-at-rest muons ("Michel" electrons), so the selection requirement of two delayed Michel electrons (one each from the π decay chain and the primary muon decay) in addition to the prompt muon largely rejects anti-neutrinos.
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: Absolute and differential cross sections for CC1π + have been measured previously using the MiniBooNE neutrino-mode data [9], and these are applied to simulation in the present analysis.
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: In this way, the residual level of agreement between data and simulation measures the accuracy of the extrapolated flux prediction discussed in the previous section.
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: To check the shape of the flux prediction, the CC1π + sample is binned in reconstructed neutrino energy E ∆ ν assuming ∆(1232) resonance and a stationary proton target:
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: where E B = 34 MeV is the binding energy, m µ is the muon mass,
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: is the ∆(1232) (nucleon) mass, p µ is the muon momentum, and θ µ is the outgoing muon angle relative to the incoming neutrino beam.
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: Results summarized in Figure 2 indicate the ν µ flux prediction is overestimated by ∼ 24% in normalization, while based on consistent results across bins of neutrino energy, the flux shape appears well-modeled.
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: This flux normalization (0.76 ± 0.11) is used exclusively in the subtraction of the ν µ contribution to theν µ CCQE sample presented later, as this CC1π + analysis is the least model-dependent, carries the smallest uncertainty of the measurements and is entirely independent of the CCQE model.
body_text.section: CC1π + ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

Stopped µ − undergo nuclear capture on carbon atoms at a rate of ∼ 8% [10], so neutrino-induced CCQE events have a significantly lower probability for producing Michel electrons compared to anti-neutrino CCQE events.
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: For this analysis, two CCQE samples are formed.
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: The selection of the two samples is identical with the exception of a requirement of a single delayed Michel electron (hereafter referred to as the "µ + e" sample) or no decay electrons (the "µ-only" sample).
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: Linear scales applied to the ν µ andν µ contributions (α ν and αν , respectively) in the simulation are determined by simultaneously requiring the ratio (µ-only)/(µ + e) and the normalization to agree between data and the simulation.
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: This yields α ν = (µ-only) data (µ + e) MC ν µ − (µ + e) data (µ-only) MC
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: where, for example, (µ-only) data is the number of data events for the µ-only sample and (µ + e) MC ν µ is the predicted ν µ contribution to the (µ + e) sample.
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: The µ-only and µ + e samples are dominated by the CCQE process, and simulation for both ν µ andν µ CCQE have been modified to reflect the model parameters observed in neutrino-mode data [12].
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: The ν µ flux measurement, 0.83 ± 0.15, is consistent and complimentary with that found in the previous section.
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: The error on the αν rate scale is larger due to conservative uncertainties placed on the interaction to cover the extrapolated model parameter assumptions; fortunately, the ν µ flux scale α ν is not very sensitive to theν µ contributions.
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: Due to the limited statistics of the µ-only sample, measurements are not made in bins of neutrino energy in order to check the ν µ flux shape as is done in the other methods.
body_text.section: µ − Capture ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement
Neutrino and anti-neutrino CCQE cross sections differ exclusively by an axial-vector interference term.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: In particular, the contribution fromν µ is suppressed in the backward scattering region relative to the incoming neutrinos.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: The µ + e sample used in the previous section is also employed in this analysis, but with slightly different selection cuts to enhance the CCQE purity.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: Simulation is separated into the predicted ν µ andν µ contributions, and a linear combination of these templates are fit to data.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: Results binned in energy are presented in Figure 2.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: Appropriate to the dominantν µ CCQE contribution to the sample, the reconstructed energy is found as in Eqn.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: 1 with the neutron mass substituted for the ∆(1232) mass.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: The angular fit finds results consistent with the CC1π + and µ − capture measurements, namely that the ν µ flux is overestimated in normalization while the shape of the flux prediction is robust.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: The results from all three analyses are consistent and complementary.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 2, the measurements indicate the prediction of the neutrino flux component of the anti-neutrino beam is consistent with a uniform reduction of ∼ 20%.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: These types of analyses may be of use to present and future precision neutrino experiments testing CP violation with neutrino and anti-neutrino beams in a non-magnetized environment.
body_text.section: CCQE Angular Fit ν µ Flux Measurement

body_text.text: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA
With the largest background to theν µ CCQE sample constrained by MiniBooNE's own data, meaningful measurements ofν µ CCQE can be made.
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: In this section the background-subtracted data is compared to the Fermi Gas model under various assumptions.
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: In the formalism, the so-called axial mass M A is the only free parameter for neutrino experiments to determine.
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: Early measurements mostly on light nuclear targets provide a combined value of M A = 1.03 ± 0.02 GeV [11].
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: The MiniBooNE measurement of ν µ CCQE on carbon yielded a significantly higher value of M A = 1.35 ± 0.17 GeV together with a mild scaling of nuclear Pauli blocking κ = 1.007 ± 0.012 [12].
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: Other high precision detectors with nuclear targets have also measured higher values of M A recently [13,14,15].
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: The MiniBooNE detector medium (C n H 2n+2 , n ∼ 20) contains a combination of quasi-free and bound proton targets for theν µ CCQE interaction.
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: Using separate axial masses for the hydrogen ("M H A ") and carbon ("M C A ") scattering components, model comparisons to data are presented in Figures 3 and 4.
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: For simultaneous consistency with the light target results and the neutrino-mode MiniBooNE measurement, the value of M H A (M C A ) is set to 1.02 (1.35) GeV for the absolute comparison, while a shape comparison is made with this prediction and also with M H A = M C A = 1.02 GeV.
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: The latter choice does not describe the data shape, while the shape provided by the former parameter set is consistent but is also roughly 20% low in normalization.
body_text.section: MODEL COMPARISONS TOν µ CCQE DATA

body_text.text: CONCLUSION
The ν µ flux in the MiniBooNEν µ beam has been measured with three independent and complementary techniques.
body_text.section: CONCLUSION

body_text.text: Results indicate the uncertain flux prediction is overestimated by ∼ 20%, while the flux shape is well-modeled.
body_text.section: CONCLUSION

body_text.text: This measurement allows a much more precise evaluation of theν µ CCQE data.
body_text.section: CONCLUSION

body_text.text: The shape of these data are consistent with an axial mass value for bound nucleon targets of 1.35 GeV, while the ratio of the data to this prediction is 1.21 ± 0.12.
body_text.section: CONCLUSION
